title: Ministers and Stewards
shortSummary: In 1 Corinthians 4, Paul emphasizes the role of apostles and ministers as faithful stewards of God's mysteries. He warns against pride and premature judgment, urging believers to recognize that true evaluation belongs to the Lord alone. Paul also contrasts the apostles’ hardships with the Corinthians’ self-assuredness, calling them to humility and faithful imitation.
timeline: c. AD 55 - Paul's Third Missionary Journey, during his ministry in Corinth

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The apostle writing this letter, defending his apostleship and urging the Corinthians to humility and faithfulness.

keyCharacters.name: Apollos
keyCharacters.description: A fellow minister mentioned by Paul as an example to teach the Corinthians not to be arrogant about human leaders.

keyCharacters.name: Timotheus (Timothy)
keyCharacters.description: Paul’s beloved and faithful son in the Lord, sent to remind the Corinthians of Paul’s teachings and ways in Christ.

definitions.definition: Those entrusted with managing or caring for something valuable, here referring to ministers who manage the mysteries of God.
Divine truths previously hidden but now revealed through Christ and the gospel.
Arrogant or prideful, inflated with self-importance.
The refuse or scum of the world, indicating how apostles were despised and rejected.

outline.heading: Apostles as Faithful Stewards
outline.description: Paul teaches that apostles are servants and stewards of Christ’s mysteries, accountable to God alone, and warns against premature human judgment.

outline.heading: Warning Against Pride and Division
outline.description: Paul uses himself and Apollos as examples to caution the Corinthians against arrogance and elevating human leaders above Scripture.

outline.heading: The Apostles’ Suffering and Humility
outline.description: Paul contrasts the Corinthians’ self-confidence with the apostles’ hardships, emphasizing their suffering and humility for Christ’s sake.

outline.heading: Paul’s Fatherly Concern and Exhortation
outline.description: Paul expresses his paternal care for the Corinthians, urging them to imitate him and reminding them of Timothy’s forthcoming visit.

outline.heading: Paul’s Coming and the Kingdom’s Power
outline.description: Paul addresses those arrogant about his delayed visit, affirming that the kingdom of God is demonstrated by power, not words, and questions how he should come to them.

application: Recognize that Christian leaders are stewards accountable to God, not to human judgment, and submit to their godly authority with humility.
Guard against pride and division by valuing Scripture above human personalities and avoiding arrogance in spiritual matters.
Embrace the reality of suffering and hardship as part of faithful Christian living, following the example of the apostles.
Imitate godly mentors and remain faithful to the gospel teachings, welcoming correction and encouragement from spiritual leaders.

keyVerses.text: Moreover it is required in stewards, that a man be found faithful.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the essential quality of faithfulness required of all who serve God.

keyVerses.text: Therefore judge nothing before the time, until the Lord come, who both will bring to light the hidden things of darkness, and will make manifest the counsels of the hearts: and then shall every man have praise of God.
keyVerses.significance: It reminds believers to withhold judgment, as only God can rightly judge the heart and motives.

keyVerses.text: Wherefore I beseech you, be ye followers of me.
keyVerses.significance: Paul calls the Corinthians to imitate his godly example, emphasizing the importance of discipleship.

keyVerses.text: For the kingdom of God is not in word, but in power.
keyVerses.significance: This verse stresses that true Christianity is demonstrated by the power of God, not merely by eloquent speech.
